Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012), where the Supreme Judicial Court emphasized the Court’s duty to intervene when substantial evidence indicates harm or risk to a child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The case does discuss the best interests of the child and affirms that judges must weigh all relevant factors, including harm or risk of harm to the child, when making custody determinations. However, it does not frame this in terms of a "material change in circumstances" standard, nor does it articulate any distinct Massachusetts doctrine about material change in circumstances triggering a duty to intervene. The opinion focuses on initial custody determination and recognition of a domestic partnership, not modification of prior orders based on changed circumstances, so using it as authority for that specific proposition misstates its holding.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’.… The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ … Despite Rose’s assertion to the contrary, the judge’s conclusion that Jill would suffer substantial harm if she were to remain in Rose’s custody… has ample support in the record…”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: Yannas does apply a ‘best interests of the child’ framework, but it is specifically in the context of removal/relocation by a custodial parent, not a general modification-of-custody standard nor an articulated requirement to prioritize “safety and welfare” in all custody matters. The opinion focuses on balancing the custodial parent’s ‘real advantage’ in relocating with the child’s best interests and the noncustodial parent’s visitation rights, not on modifying custody or emphasizing child safety as a distinct controlling factor. Thus, it does not support the proposition as stated.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change… and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and further supported by the rationale in *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), which requires courts to prioritize the safety and welfare of children in all custody mattes.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: Custody of Kali does reaffirm that the ‘best interests of the child’ is the governing standard in custody matters and cites Yannas for the general principle that the child’s best interests are paramount. However, Kali is not a relocation/removal case and does not apply or elaborate the specific Yannas standard; instead, it interprets G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) and emphasizes stability and continuity with a satisfactory caregiver, not a generic mandate to ‘prioritize safety and welfare in all custody matters.’ Thus, relying on Kali as direct authority for the Yannas removal standard or as a broad safety-first rule overstates its holding.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The ‘best interests of the child’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt…; Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’). … General Laws c. 209C, § 10(a), … gives direction to the judge’s consideration of a child’s ‘best interests’ by ‘evincing a general intent on the part of the Legislature to maintain the bonds between the child and her caregiver.’”}

*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that a parent’s inability to provide a safe and stable environment for their child, particularly when linked to substance abuse concerns, constitutes sufficient grounds for custody modification.
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The opinion in Blixt v. Blixt concerns the constitutionality and interpretation of Massachusetts’ grandparent visitation statute and related due process and equal protection principles. It does not address custody modification standards, parental unfitness findings, or substance abuse–related instability as grounds to change custody. Because the case neither discusses nor establishes rules for custody modification based on a parent’s inability to provide a safe and stable environment, it does not support the claimed proposition.
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: “It cannot be disputed that the State has a compelling interest to protect children from actual or potential harm. … This interest is expressed in a variety of statutes and proceedings, ranging from the complete severance of parental rights on a judge’s finding of parental unfitness, to the limitation of parental choices in the areas, for example, of education, health care, and safety.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns relocation and statutory custody rights of an unmarried, fit mother under the Massachusetts paternity statute, not custody modification based on parental inability to provide a safe and stable environment or substance abuse. The court repeatedly emphasizes that the mother is an "unquestionably fit" parent and focuses on statutory interpretation and relocation standards, not on unfitness or instability as grounds for modifying custody. Thus, it does not establish or affirm the proposition that parental inability to provide a safe, stable environment linked to substance abuse justifies custody modification.

After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart... and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G.
